etymologies: mid 17th century (in baccalaureate (sense 2 of the noun)): from French baccalauréat or medieval Latin baccalaureatus, from baccalaureus ‘bachelor’. The earlier form baccalarius was altered by wordplay to conform with bacca lauri ‘laurel berry’, because of the laurels awarded to scholars. baccalaureate (sense 1 of the noun) dates from 1970

definitions: an examination intended to qualify successful candidates for higher education.
shortDefinitions: examination intended to qualify successful candidates for higher education

definitions: a religious service held at some educational institutions before commencement, containing a farewell sermon to the graduating class.
shortDefinitions: religious service held at some educational institutions before commencement, containing farewell sermon
